PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

NO. 2

SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES

A word of explanation to the person answering the questionnaire

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual was asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions have all not apply to your experiences others may prove impossible for you to answer so don't worry about leaving blank spaces.

The extra sheets of paper if there is not sufficient space to answer the questions, leave extra sheets of paper if there is not sufficient space to answer the questions.

Don't hesitate to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the question.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in western Canada before 1914, and may be especially young who has personal experience of the pioneer years whatever born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire.

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as any other. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about being unable to answer all the questions. Don't hesitate to give details, or describe particularly interesting experiences.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1924, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

1. Your full name: Alice Crompton Richardson

2. Your address: [Address not visible]

3. Date: March 28, 1957

4. Where were you born? (Gave name of place and country): Liverpool, England

5. What was your father's name and occupation?: William Richardson, Builder

6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year): August, 1905

7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible.

8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child" etc., I was in my 1st year)

9. What were your reasons for coming West?

My brother wanted to farm; he was a carpenter but had a breakdown in health and my father having died we broke up our home and my mother, myself, and myself went to Canada and applied for land farming, we left in 1914

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it?)

There were several pamphlets and advertisements issued by the Canadian government, advertising of the advantages of life in Western Canada.

Also one of my brothers friends came out to Saskatchewan and he had gone to Alberta after he came out.

Moreover, my brother was satisfied with the place.

We are delighted here. We have no relatives in Canada.

III. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

They understood that my brother George wanted to farm and land in the prairie country.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?

My mother Ellen, brothers George and I, and a small crew of old timers together.

13. What means of transportation did you use?

We left England on the Canadian steamship "Poveshuken" and arrived three days later in Vancouver, British Columbia, via a freight train to the new town of North Battleford.

14. What incidents of the journey went do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.).

There were several young men on the train coming out to take up land; and they brought it with a good poke to call out "Wanted" for others. Otherwise we had a quiet journey on the steamer of the night. It was when they called "Heads please."

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

On the new Lots of Portage, near the end of the line, and off the main road.

16. Where did you settle or take up land? George homesteaded on the east corner.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

I worked with my brothers on Blair's farm and have lived here ever since.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How, after you came?

I lived at home and did dressmaking.
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommendation? If so, name any family.

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came west tell when they came and where they settled.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?

We had quite a few experiences in our early days. Sometimes we had to cut down trees during a storm and had to move a house due to wind and snow. We also faced many hardships and difficulties but managed to survive.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (For business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of conveyance?

After we got a house and enough land to go to North Dakota and work hard, we saved up enough money to buy a team of oxen and a plow. We then bought a horse and a cart and started farming. It was hard work but we managed to make ends meet.

After we got a house and a good road to go to North Battleford every week end and back. But when the Saskatchewan General Hospital meetings started and the organized church came out to hold revival meetings here, we had to attend from Medicine Hat, and 1907 every second Sunday. We had to go to Medicine Hat, and then we have not had a second minister from Medicine Hat since then, except for one.

We came here to make a home for ourselves not with any idea of making a fortune in four hours.

But how much a living and how no sale.

The famous Round Top Cemetery, 1914.

28. Did you continue to travel there? (Indicate any changes due to appearance, better means of travel, etc.)

We go to North Battleford to trade; it is nearest.

29. How often did you shop in the early days?

We had only a team store at first, about 2 hours each

30. Then (if ever) did people in your district start going to town regularly on Saturdays?

Friday so often the main shopping day for farmers.

31. What kind of articles did you buy through the mail order catalogue?

What kind of articles did you buy by mail order? How much did you pay for your total purchases?

We bought goods by mail order early days.

The early farmers often charged a commission.

But now we mostly shop in North Battleford.

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it?

December 1914, North Battleford Co., Ltd.

33. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time were you permanent? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? Then did you make this decision?

We came here to make a home for ourselves, not with any idea of making a fortune, we have never been very particular, every little helps,

but have made a living and have no debts.

36. If you or those members of your family have held public offices or have been active in any organization, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

A homesteader who worked on the homestead until 1911, and was still in the homestead condition in 1955.

I was Secretary treasurer for some years and at one time held an office for a few years.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were first to have or do something in the district, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

(Such as owning the first automobile, continuing organizing the first lodge, etc.)

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, post offices, villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.) Try to give (1) name and occupation of person suggesting place-name; (2) date of adoption; (3) date of change; (4) any changes in name since the first name and given date and reason for change.

(1) Glenmore was suggested from one farm by Glenmore.

(2) A new house was built in 1907, thus changing the name of the community.

(3) A farmer's name was given a few years later.

(4) The name was changed to Glennmore by the district.

The homesteaders seemed to get confused with Glennmore and received permission to rename it Glennmore.

The homesteaders seemed to get confused with Glennmore and received permission to rename it Glennmore.
